context: The levels of 1-octen-3-ol, 1-pentanol, hexanal and 2-pentanone measured in non-sterilized samples of pork at the time of spoilage did not cause spoilage of sterilized pork indicating that chemical lipid oxidation most likely did not cause spoilage of the non-sterilized samples. It is possible, however, that lipid oxidation products contributed to the overall odor of spoiled pork, especially in Collar W that had higher concentrations of hexanal, 1-octen-3-ol and 1-pentanol than any of the other pork samples at the time of spoilage. Interestingly, in a study by Argyri et al. (2015) hexanal was associated with fresh rather than spoiled meat which was not the case in our study. Although all samples contained hexanal, the related 1-hexanol was exclusively observed in pork collar which had a higher pH than pork loin (Table 2). Higher pH has been suggested to facilitate enzymatic reduction of hexanal to 1-hexanol in soy beans (Matoba et al., 1989). The reaction can be considered favorable in food because 1-hexanol has a lower odor threshold than hexanal. In conclusion, this study showed that P. phosphoreum can be predominating in bacterial communities of high-oxygen MAP raw pork at the time of spoilage.
